text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days.
Let me try to break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because taking the elevator down would save him from climbing up 10 flights of stairs, which could be tiring, especially if he's in a hurry for work.
In the evening, when he returns home, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the remaining three floors to his apartment.
Hmm, why would he do that? Maybe because the elevator stops at his floor, or perhaps he doesn't want to walk all the way up from the ground floor.
If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor, he only has to walk 3 floors, which is manageable, especially if it's not too far.
On the other hand, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
That seems a bit odd because he's already on the 10th floor.

Why would he take the elevator back up?

Wait, maybe I'm misunderstanding something.
Let me visualize the building.
The man lives on the 10th floor.
The ground floor is the 1st floor.
So, in the morning, he goes from 10th to 1st.
In the evening, he goes from 1st to 7th via elevator, then walks from 7th to 10th.
On rainy days, he goes from 10th back up to 10th? That doesn't make sense because he's already on the 10th floor.
Unless there's something else going on.
Oh, maybe I'm misinterpreting the floors.
Sometimes buildings can have different ways of numbering floors.
For example, the ground floor might be considered the 0th floor, or maybe the first floor is the ground floor.
If that's the case, then the man lives on the 10th floor, which would be higher up.
Let me adjust that.
If the ground floor is the 1st floor, then in the morning, he goes from 10th to 1st.
In the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up 3 floors to 10th.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
Wait, that's what he does every evening, so that doesn't explain the rainy day change.
Maybe the problem is that on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk up the stairs from the 7th floor to the 10th.
Perhaps the stairs are slippery when it's raining, so he takes the elevator instead.
That makes sense.
So, normally, he takes the elevator down in the morning and up to the 7th floor in the evening, then walks up.
But on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk the stairs, so he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
Yes, that must be it.
The reason is that on rainy days, the stairs are wet and slippery, making it dangerous to walk up them.
Therefore, he uses the elevator to avoid slipping on the stairs.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days because the stairs are slippery, making it unsafe to walk up from the 7th floor.
He uses the elevator to avoid falling on the wet stairs.
